title: What you don't know about who you will become

options.label: A
options.text: Why do people get tattoos removed?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Why do people get married young?

options.label: D
options.text: Why do people work hard to lose weight?

multiple-choice.question: What is the "magical point in life" where change suddenly goes from a gallop to a crawl, according to the speaker?

options.label: D
options.text: Now, wherever now happens to be

multiple-choice.question: What is the "end of history" illusion, according to the speaker?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people vastly overestimate how much change they will experience over the next 10 years

options.label: A
options.text: That people's values change drastically over time

options.label: B
options.text: That people's values remain the same over time

options.label: C
options.text: That people vastly underestimate how much their values will change over the next 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: That people vastly overestimate how much their values will change over the next 10 years

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: That people's personalities change drastically over time

options.label: B
options.text: That people's personalities remain the same over time

options.label: C
options.text: That people vastly underestimate how much their personalities will change over the next 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: That people vastly overestimate how much their personalities will change over the next 10 years

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they underestimate the stability of their preferences

options.text: Because of the ease of remembering versus the difficulty of imagining

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the difficulty of remembering versus the ease of imagining

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the power of intuition

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the influence of others

options.label: D

title: What is the biggest single-celled organism? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why unicellular organisms cannot grow to the size of multicellular organisms like elephants or blue whales?

options.label: B
options.text: Insufficient surface area to volume ratio

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the cellular membrane in a cell?

options.label: B
options.text: To act as the doorway into and out of the cell

multiple-choice.question: As a cell grows in size, what happens to its surface area to volume ratio?
Why would a huge cell eventually die and disintegrate?

options.label: C
options.text: Due to insufficient surface area for exchange

multiple-choice.question: What is an advantage of having multiple smaller cells in an organism?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced ability to adapt to environments

options.label: C
options.text: Improved surface area to volume ratio

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced impact of individual cell damage

What is the function of microvilli in the small intestine?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase surface area for exchange

options.label: B
options.text: It has a small surface area to volume ratio

options.label: C
options.text: It is a single-celled organism with multiple nuclei

multiple-choice.question: How does Caulerpa taxifolia enhance its surface area?

options.label: B
options.text: They have multiple nuclei and cell divisions

options.label: C
options.text: They have multiple nuclei but lack cell divisions

title: This Video Will Make You Angry

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of "thought germs" in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Thoughts are like living organisms that can be transmitted through the air.

options.label: B
options.text: Thoughts are like germs that can infect our brains and spread through social media.

options.label: C
options.text: Thoughts are like viruses that can harm our computers.

options.label: D
options.text: Thoughts are like bacteria that can be found in our environment.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the most effective way for a thought germ to spread?
What is the term used in the transcript to describe the process of thought germs changing and adapting as they spread?
According to the transcript, what is the result of thought germs competing with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They become weaker and less effective.

options.label: B
options.text: They become stronger and more effective.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used in the transcript to describe the relationship between two thought germs that work together to spread?
According to the transcript, what is the effect of a thought germ using the "you're with us or against us" tool?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes it harder for neutral brains to resist.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it easier for neutral brains to resist.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on neutral brains.

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects people who are already on one side of the argument.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of two opposing groups arguing with each other, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They eventually come to an agreement.

options.label: B
options.text: They become more divided and entrenched in their positions.

options.label: C
options.text: They start to ignore each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more open-minded and willing to listen to each other.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens to thought germs that are not emotionally charged?

options.label: A
options.text: They spread rapidly and become very popular.

options.label: B
options.text: They spread slowly but remain effective.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not spread at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the transcript regarding thought germs and the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: The internet is a great place to spread thought germs and make them go viral.

options.label: B
options.text: The internet is a breeding ground for thought germs that can be both good and bad.

options.label: C
options.text: The internet is a place where thought germs can be controlled and regulated.

options.label: D
options.text: The internet is a place where thought germs are irrelevant.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key to maintaining a healthy brain in the face of thought germs?

options.label: A
options.text: Being open-minded and willing to listen to all ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: Being cautious of thoughts that have passed through many brains and poke at our weaknesses.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring all thoughts and ideas that we disagree with.

options.label: D
options.text: Actively seeking out and engaging with thought germs that challenge our views.

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Don't eat the marshmallow!

options.text: Children were asked to share a toy with another child.

options.text: Three out of four children ate the marshmallow.

options.label: C
options.text: They had mixed results, with some doing well and others not.

options.label: B
options.text: They were all in trouble and had bad grades.

options.label: C
options.text: They had mixed results, with some doing well and others not.

options.text: To learn about the education system in Colombia.

options.label: C
options.text: Three out of four children ate the marshmallow.

options.text: All the children ate the marshmallow.

options.label: D

title: Why the metric system matters - Matt Anticole

options.label: B
options.text: To standardize measurements based on mathematical and natural relationships

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the use of fractions

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It reduced the power of the church

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the government to collect taxes more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: It promoted the use of local units

options.label: D
options.text: It was only used by the nobility

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They think it is too precise

options.label: B
options.text: By universal constants, such as the speed of light
